guide.title: Gentoo E-mail System
guide.abstract: This document describes what you, as Gentoo Developer, can expect from our new e-mail system .

body.p: This document describes the various options for checking your gentoo.org email address. You can opt for having the e-mails forwarded to a specific e-mail address, or let them stay on the dev.gentoo.org server to which you can connect using your favorite e-mail client with pop3s or imaps (the secure implementations of POP3 and IMAP respectively).

If you want to have your e-mails forwarded to another e-mail address, you should log on to dev.gentoo.org and put the e-mail address in ~/.forward. Logging on to dev.gentoo.org is similar to cvs.gentoo.org: you'll be using the same keys.

pre.caption: Forwarding e-mails to another e-mail address

body.pre: $ ssh -l username dev.gentoo.org username@emu username $ echo new.e-mail@address.com > ~/.forward username@emu username $ exit
body.note: Old(er) developers who want to use this situation don't have to do anything. We have already created all ~/.forward's with their current e-mail address.
body.p: If you at some point want to change the e-mail address to which the e-mails should be forwarded, change the content of the ~/.forward file to the new e-mail address.

If you want to use the mailbox on dev.gentoo.org, you must make sure that there is no .forward in your home directory. Doing this requires access to dev.gentoo.org (duh). Accessing dev.gentoo.org is no different than accessing cvs.gentoo.org: you'll be using the same keys.
There are some things you must know about your mailbox on dev.gentoo.org:

ul.li: There is a quota on the amount of data you can store on dev.gentoo.org. This is currently 100 Mb so the chance that e-mails are lost because you exceeded the quota are slim. However, if you plan on taking a vacation and you think that the quota can be exceeded during your vacation, have the e-mails forwarded to another e-mail address where you have no such quota.
You can only access it using pop3s or imaps (see the following chapter).
The password to access the mailbox is the same password you can set on dev.gentoo.org using passwd.

body.p: pop3s is the secure variant of POP3, the Post Office Protocol version 3. POP3 is a pull-protocol, meaning that e-mails are pulled from the server to your local disk.
To set up your favorite e-mail client for pop3s, use the following settings:
body.warn: POP3 without SSL is not supported! It is insecure because it transmits the password in plain tekst, which is a Bad Thing (TM).
body.note: The dev.gentoo.org password is the same as the one used on cvs.gentoo.org (which is now SSH-key only). If you don't know your password anymore, ask klieber, sj7trunks or peitolm to reset your password).
body.p: For instance, if you are using fetchmail to fetch your e-mails, your .fetchmailrc should read something like this:
body.pre: poll dev.gentoo.org proto pop3 user username pass password nokeep ssl
body.p: If you are using sylpheed for your e-mails, create a new account and make sure that the Receive tab uses POP3 and the SSL tab has the Use SSL for POP3 connection selected.
If you are using mutt, you're smart enough to figure this one out yourself.

imaps is the secure variant of IMAP, the Internet Message Acces Protocol version 4. IMAP is a push-protocol, meaning that e-mails stay on the remote server and you can manage seperate mailboxes on that server.
To set up your favorite e-mail client for imaps, use the following settings:
body.warn: IMAP without SSL is not supported! It is insecure because it uses static authentication, which is a Bad Thing (TM).
body.note: The dev.gentoo.org password is the same as the one used on cvs.gentoo.org (which is now SSH-key only). If you don't know your password anymore, ask klieber, sj7trunks or peitolm to reset your password).
body.p: For instance, if you are using fetchmail to fetch your e-mails, your .fetchmailrc should read something like this:
body.pre: poll dev.gentoo.org proto imap user username pass password nokeep ssl
body.p: If you are using mutt, you're smart enough to figure this one out yourself.

section.title: Using dev.gentoo.org as a mail relay server

body.warn: Do not do this unless absolutely necessary. Please use your ISPs relay server whenever possible.
body.p: If you need a relay-server desperately and have no other means of sending e-mails, you can use dev.gentoo.org as a relayserver. To do this, you must first provide it with a password (not your dev.gentoo.org password!).
body.pre: $ ssh -l username dev.gentoo.org username@emu username $ echo "ChosenPassword" > ~/.asmtppasswd username@emu username $ chmod 0740 ~/.asmtppasswd username@emu username $ chmod o+x ~/ username@emu username $ exit
body.impo: Please do not use your regular login password for your asmtp password. Instead, choose a random password and use that or emerge makepasswd and run makepasswd --chars=8 to have it select one for you
body.note: ~/.asmtppasswd must be owned by the 'mail' group. This should be the default setting. If you notice, however, that your ~/.asmtppasswd file is group-owned by a different group, please contact one of the infrastructure sysadmins to fix it.
body.p: Now setup your e-mail client to use dev.gentoo.org as the SMTP server. Select yes when asked if the server uses authentication. If you get the choice, select cram-md5 as the hash-method. Use your username and the provided password from above for authentication.

section.title: What happens when dev.gentoo.org goes down?

body.p: When dev.gentoo.org goes down, e-mails will stay in the mailqueue on mail.gentoo.org and will be delivered whenever dev.gentoo.org is up again.

section.title: Can I use procmail on dev.gentoo.org?

body.p: Yes you can.

section.title: Can I use SpamAssassin on dev.gentoo.org?

body.p: Yes you can.

section.title: Why don't you set up a system-wide (spam|virus) filter?

body.p: Spam and virus filtering is not 100% accurate and there are risks of losing legitimate email when using these tools. Consequently, the infrastructure team makes the necessary tools available to the developers to use if they so choose.

section.title: Are my e-mails or the contents of my home directory backed up regularly?

body.p: No, it's the responsibility of the individual to back up their own important files and mail.
